explanation: BaSO4 is isostructural with other MSO4 (M = Ca, Sr, Pb) examples in the dataset. SrSO4 and CaSO4 have very large band gaps (~5.9–6.0 eV) and formation energies around -2.61 to -2.68 eV/atom. PbSO4 shows a somewhat reduced gap (≈3.99 eV) and a slightly less negative formation energy, likely due to Pb electronic states. Ba2+ is larger than Sr2+ and similar in chemistry (no low-lying f or Pb-like 6s states), so the band gap is expected to remain large and comparable to SrSO4/CaSO4 but possibly slightly reduced by modest cation size/coordination effects. The lattice parameters should be slightly expanded relative to SrSO4 (a = 5.3428 Å, b = 6.8705 Å, c = 8.3558 Å, V = 306.7 Å3) and close to or slightly larger than PbSO4 (V ≈ 317.6 Å3). The formation energy is expected to be similar to SrSO4 (around -2.6 to -2.7 eV/atom). Given these trends, I estimate a modest expansion of the unit cell and a band gap comparable to other alkaline-earth sulfates.

BaSO4 (barite) is chemically analogous to the listed alkaline-earth sulfates (CaSO4, SrSO4) and to PbSO4. Cell volumes for the series Ca -> Sr -> Pb in the provided data increase (Ca 293.6 Å3, Sr 306.7 Å3, Pb 317.6 Å3) as the cation size increases; Ba2+ is larger than Sr2+ and Pb2+, so I predict lattice parameters slightly larger than those for SrSO4/PbSO4 but of the same orthorhombic motif. The band gap for alkaline-earth sulfates (Ca, Sr) in the list is large (~5.9–6.0 eV); BaSO4 is expected to have a similarly large insulating gap (I therefore predict ~5.7 eV). Formation energies per atom for Ca and Sr sulfates are around -2.6 to -2.7 eV/atom; BaSO4 should be similar, so I predict -2.67 eV/atom. The lattice parameters (a, b, c) are chosen by extrapolating the small monotonic increases seen across the cation series, giving a modest increase relative to SrSO4/PbSO4 and producing a unit-cell volume consistent with that trend.

Predictions are based on trends among Ba-containing tetrahedral oxyanion analogues in the provided dataset (especially BaSeO4, BaCrO4, BaFeO4 and BaCO4). BaSeO4 (Se in place of S) has a band gap of 3.72 eV and lattice a,b,c = 5.692, 7.403, 9.100 Å (V ≈ 383.45 Å3). Sulfur is smaller and more electronegative than selenium, which typically increases the band gap slightly and shrinks the lattice relative to the selenate. BaCrO4 and BaFeO4 show similar a,b,c ranges (a ≈ 5.54–5.62 Å, b ≈ 7.36–7.42 Å, c ≈ 9.15–9.20 Å) and volumes ≈ 373–383 Å3, supporting a modest contraction for the sulfate vs selenate. Formation energies per atom for Ba-oxyanion compounds cluster near −2.0 to −2.5 eV/atom (BaSeO4: −2.156 eV/atom; BaCrO4: −2.461 eV/atom; BaFeO4: −1.732 eV/atom). Sulfate is expected to be thermodynamically comparable to or slightly more stable than the selenate, so a formation energy a bit lower (more negative) than BaSeO4 is predicted. Overall I predict a modestly larger band gap than BaSeO4 and a slightly smaller cell volume.

BaSO4 (barite) is an ionic sulfate with a compact orthorhombic cell (Pnma) and a large band gap typical of sulfates. The predicted lattice constants are close to known barite-like values and give a cell volume slightly larger than BaBeF4 (which has a smaller anion). The formation energy per atom is estimated from typical standard formation enthalpies of BaSO4 (~-1467 kJ/mol ≈ -15.2 eV per formula unit) divided by 6 atoms per formula unit → ≈ -2.53 eV/atom. The band gap is estimated in the range expected for insulating sulfates (≈5–6 eV).

BaSO4 (barite) adopts the orthorhombic Pnma barite structure with lattice parameters well documented experimentally. I used the experimental crystallographic cell as the basis for the lattice parameters and volume, estimated the optical band gap from reported UV/optical measurements for barite (wide-gap insulator), and converted standard formation enthalpy data to an approximate DFT-style formation energy per atom to be consistent with the analogue dataset magnitudes. The formation energy per atom is computed by taking the standard formation enthalpy of BaSO4 (~-1360 to -1375 kJ/mol) and converting to eV per atom (1 eV = 96.485 kJ/mol) and dividing by 6 atoms/formula unit, giving about -2.3 to -2.4 eV/atom. The band gap is an experimental optical gap around ~5.2 eV; I report a representative value of 5.3 eV to reflect that it is a wide-gap insulating sulfate.

BaSO4 adopts the barite (orthorhombic, Pnma) structure; I used published/crystallographic values for the barite lattice constants and volume and literature thermochemistry for formation energy plus typical optical-gap reports for sulfates. Reported room-temperature lattice parameters for barite are about a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.153 Å (giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 346.8 Å^3). The optical/electronic gap of BaSO4 is large (insulating sulfate); literature values cluster near ~6 eV, so I predict 6.0 eV. The standard enthalpy of formation of BaSO4 is about −1462 kJ/mol (≈ −15.16 eV per formula unit); dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit gives ≈ −2.53 eV/atom, which I report as the formation-energy prediction.

BaSO4 adopts the orthorhombic barite structure (Pnma) and is a wide-gap ionic insulator. The lattice constants and cell volume are taken from standard crystallographic data for barite; they are consistent with volumes of other large A–(polyatomic anion) crystals in the analogue set (e.g., BaBeF4 has similar overall cell size though fluoride anions are smaller than SO4). The formation energy is estimated from experimental standard formation enthalpy of BaSO4 (~ -1467 kJ/mol) converted to eV per atom (≈ -15.21 eV per formula unit ÷ 6 atoms ≈ -2.54 eV/atom), which is also in the range of stable ionic compounds shown in the analogues. The band gap is taken from reported optical/experimental values for bulk BaSO4 (a wide-gap insulator around 5–5.5 eV); DFT (PBE) values could be lower, but a best estimate for the true gap is ~5.3 eV.

BaSO4 (barite) is an ionic sulfate with SO4 tetrahedra and large Ba2+ cations. Analogues in the provided set are mostly A–(tetrahedral-anion) salts whose unit-cell volumes cluster in the few-hundred Å^3 range and whose band gaps are large (insulating, several eV). Experimentally reported barite lattice constants are ≈8.884 Å, 5.457 Å, 7.157 Å (orthorhombic Pnma), giving a unit-cell volume ≈347 Å^3; I adopt those well-established crystallographic values. Sulfates are wide-gap insulators; reported optical/gap estimates for BaSO4 are in the ~5.0–6.0 eV range, so I predict a band gap of 5.6 eV. Formation energies per atom for stable ionic tetrahedral salts in the analogues span roughly −1.6 to −3.3 eV/atom; BaSO4 is chemically very stable, so I predict a formation energy of about −2.40 eV/atom (per atom). These choices are consistent with the stability and insulating character seen across the analogue set.
